slidelink.displaytext: Questions to Guide Your Data Search
Data & GIS Help Desk â€“ Kennedy Library, Rm. 111, Hub 24

search.slidetext: finding data tutorial welcome

after the tutorial, complete the guided worksheet to find data on your topic. finding data notebook it will take 30 minutes with a few questions that check your understanding of the material. time this tutorial covers the ways to find data and visualizations for your assignment. purpose tutorial instructions 1 2 3
effective data search strategies purpose of the tutorial why data? business example journalism example table example

data production is a process collected data primary data collection, typically not available data available for further exploration and analysis published datasets summary datasets key facts & statistics summary tables simple visualizations more involved to find, understand, and use. easier to find, use, and communicate.

questions to guide your data search collected data published data reported data secondary data portals do other sites aggregate data on this topic? 4 literature review, link articles to data sources and repositories how has this topic been researched by others? 3 news articles, links to data sources and research articles how has this been reported in the news? 2 government agencies, international organizations, institutes, academic research centers who collects and publishes data on this topic? 1

research data portals research data portals research data portals research data portals government data sources government data sources government data sources government data sources secondary data portals secondary data portals secondary data portals secondary data portals library databases library databases library databases library databases web search web search web search web search data in the news data in the news data in the news data in the news published datasets published datasets published datasets published datasets peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations what do you need? data search strategies where do you search? data presentation types

summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations published datasets published datasets published datasets published datasets published datasets peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information what do you need? data in terms of how it is presented select and explore each hexagon before proceeding

peer reviewed journal articles contain existing visualizations of research findings and methodologies. example 1: high-quality illustration that reaches multiple audiences. example 2: requires technical knowledge to understand the visualization and is more typical of what you will encounter. the audience here is researchers in the field, which would require translation for a general audience. news organizations and journalists produce high-quality visualizations for a general audience. they also provide context and analysis. for example, this new york times visualization compares mass shootings in the u.s. to other countries. the visual clearly shows that the u.s. is an outlier. to make the most of a google image search, use different keywords in addition to your topic. the terms below are suggestions for narrowing your search to data-related images. [topic] visualization [topic] data [topic] statistics peer-reviewed papers high-quality journalism google images search sometimes you donâ€™t need to re-invent the wheel. if you need to illustrate a concept using data or visualizations, find an existing high-quality figure that you can use, and cite accordingly. existing visualizations 30 view more view more view more view more view more view more view more view more view more

published datasets on a given topic can be very extensive, and itâ€™s often necessary to spend time to become familiar with the particulars of this data. as you get familiar with a topic, and are looking to dive in deeper, consider exploring the published data to extract further insights. statista is one of kennedy libraryâ€™s subscription databases. it is a statistics portal which provides direct access to quantitative data on media, business, finance, politics, and a wide variety of other areas of interest or markets. get unlimited downloads, source citations and direct use or export of results in powerpoint, excel pdf and graphic (png) formats. summary datasets statista view more view more view more a summary dataset is data on a topic that has already been compiled and summarized from the underlying published datasets. it can provide a concise overview of the primary or main findings from a particular study â€“ an initial view of the big picture.

published datasets looking for more than existing summary datasets? if so, look for underlying published datasets, which contain the more complete observations and attributes (rows and columns of data). they allow you to conduct your own exploration of the data, and to create new summaries, visualizations, or analysis. summary dataset published dataset keep in mind! non-summarized published datasets can be extensive, technical, and contain obtuse documentation. it takes time to become familiar with the data in order to draw valid and defensible conclusions.

peer reviewed information keep in mind! most articles are written with a technical audience in mind. they can be dense, full of jargon, and graphically limited. it may take additional design effort to translate the available, high quality information, into a format that is compelling for a different audience. peer reviewed literature can be a great source of high quality information, including data and visualizations to further your research. in addition to the text itself, look for: summary tables or statistical results process diagrams, images, and data visualizations research datasets linked in an accessible repository, or as supplemental material to the publication

library databases library databases library databases library databases library databases government data sources government data sources government data sources government data sources government data sources web search web search web search web search web search secondary data portals secondary data portals secondary data portals secondary data portals secondary data portals data in the news data in the news data in the news data in the news data in the news where do you search? data search strategies research data portals research data portals research data portals research data portals research data portals select and explore each hexagon before proceeding

peer reviewed literature in library databases library or academic databases are a gateway to peer reviewed literature. as you look for research studies on a topic, remember that these articles can be a great source of summary data, images, and visualizations beyond the text. while youâ€™re not likely to find datasets themselves within traditional library databases, it is through the research articles that you can find links to the authoritative data used by researchers. kennedy library databases google scholar lib.calpoly.edu library website databases research articles data get started onesearch

web search looking for data on a new topic, start broadly with a general web search. become familiar with the landscape of existing information about this topic. rather than seeking datasets themselves, general web search can be most effective for finding the resources that lead to the specific datasets youâ€™re looking for. keep in mind! who collects data on this topic? how is this reported in the news? how is this topic being studied by researchers? [topic] statistics [topic] open data [topic] datasets [topic] research data search tips refine by [timeframe] and [geography]

data usa combines multiple government data sources into a single well-designed resource for data on places, industries, jobs, or universities. data can be downloaded as existing visualizations or as summary data tables. social explorer provides a convenient interface to visualize and access detailed demographic data such as median income, unemployment, and race or ethnicity. this data can be explored as a web map or exported for further analysis. statista provides small summary datasets in the form of data tables or visuals (e.g., bar charts or line charts). these can be easily downloaded, adapted and cited for use in reports or presentations. secondary data portals see data sources list see data sources list see data sources list social explorer data usa secondary data portals are sites that gather and provide access to data from a variety of original sources. they give a more consistent and user-friendly experience when searching for data across multiple sources. statista select the examples

re3data.org is a repository of research data repositories. it provides a guide (from acustics to zoology) for finding a repository for a specific discipline. the harvard dataverse is a data repository of over 100,000 datasets that spans thousands of academic institutions. researchers from many disciplines can publish research data for others to utilize. inter-university consortium for political and social research (icpsr) contains datasets used primarily in academic research in political and social sciences. this is an example of data organized by discipline. research data portals see data sources list see data sources list see data sources list harvard dataverse re3data.org as researchers conduct new and original research, the data collected in these studies is published and available for re-use by other researchers and the public. find specific datasets associated with a particular study or gain more familiarity with the types of data collected within a given discipline. icpsr select the examples

dea database: where the pain pills went. washington post. july 16, 2019. â€œamericans make up about 4.4 percent of the global population but own 42 percent of the worldâ€™s guns. from 1966 to 2012, 31 percent of the gunmen in mass shootings worldwide were american, according to a 2015 study by adam lankford, a professor at the university of alabama.â€ what explains u.s. mass shootings? international comparisons suggest an answer. new york times. nov. 7, 2017. data source: small arms survey what explains u.s. mass shootings? international comparisons suggest an answer. new york times. nov. 7, 2017. data in the news a useful strategy for finding datasets is to track down the data used in news reporting on a topic. look at the captions for attribution. sometimes, these are linked to the data source, but not always. 1 look for references to researchers or government agencies, and other clues about the underlying published data that is being used. 2 select the strategies for examples 3 look for links to datasets made available by the news organization itself.

government data sources represent a huge proportion of available data. when you consider your research question, identify which agency and which level of government is most likely to provide data on your topic. two components to keep in mind are the level of government (international to local) and the discipline area (e.g., demographics, economics, environment, crime). government data sources international open data index un data eu data world bank get started national epa nasa us census state county city datasf la county open data ca open data portal ca dept. public health data.gov global open data index

the best places to find non-summarized published datasets are in research data portals and government sources. the best places to find summarized data is secondary data portals and government data sources. the best places to find ready-made visualizations are web searches and, specifically, news sources. the best places to find peer reviewed information is in library databases. web searches too will lead you back to access via library subscriptions. summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets library databases library databases library databases library databases government data sources government data sources government data sources government data sources match your data need with the best places to search web search web search web search web search secondary data portals secondary data portals secondary data portals secondary data portals data in the news data in the news data in the news data in the news existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations published datasets published datasets published datasets published datasets peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information what do you need? where do you search? data search strategies research data portals research data portals research data portals research data portals data presentation types hover over the data types hexagons to see the matching search strategies.
â€œfinding data: general web searching,â€ kennedy library, oct. 1, 2019. watch this video to see an example of how a dataset was located by starting with a general web search.

the notebook is a worksheet that guides your search for data sources on your topic. fill out the online form and hit submit at the bottom. you will receive a copy of your submission that you can share with your instructor. purpose instructions finding data notebook bit.ly/data-notebook now that youâ€™ve completed the tutorial, you are ready to search for data sources on your topic!

meet with the data & gis specialist, russ white, or meet with our skilled student peer assistants located on the 1st floor of kennedy library, at the data & gis desk in rm 111 in hub24. see staff hours & availability for hours to drop-in or to make an appointment. staff hours & availability we provide help for finding datasets and using software tools, building skills, applying gis and data visualization, and more. data & gis help desk â€“ kennedy library, rm. 111, hub 24

give feedback give feedback give feedback restart tutorial restart tutorial restart tutorial thank you for taking the time to learn about data search strategies and sources! we hope you feel more confident about searching for data. thank you
knowledge check questions answer the following scenarios and questions to check your understanding of data search strategies.

remember that a published dataset may be more difficult to find, and have more information than you need, initially. it may be best to search for data that is already summarized, before delving further into the topic for more exploration. yes, thereâ€™s likely to be some good summary data that would help provide context for your audience. yes, like summary datasets, there may be existing visuals. on this topic, many visuals are geared toward illustrating the technology or the process, which also may turn out to be valuable in the presentation. while peer reviewed articles are high quality, they are often very focused, and may not provide a good sense of overall context or provide good background data. summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets summary datasets existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations existing visualizations peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information peer reviewed information for an upcoming presentation, youâ€™re required to utilize data, specifically to help introduce and provide context on the topic of facial recognition technology. what type of data product would you search for first? scenario one published datasets published datasets published datasets published datasets

while you're likely to see data presented in peer reviewed papers on the topic, these can be focused very narrowly on the particular aspect of the topic presented in the research paper. yes, and with an effective search you could find credible news or other technical reporting that may lead to datasets, researchers or other connections to underlying data sources. youâ€™ll also become more familiar with the terminology associated with the topic, to continue to refine your searches. as with the information presented in a peer-reviewed publication, data within a research data portal will be focused narrowly. as you delve into your topic further, and wish to explore these datasets, this could be a high quality source of data for analysis. often, diving into government data sources directly can be difficult to navigate, without already having an in-depth understanding of the topic. in addition, for new and emerging issues such as this, there may not yet be a large amount of data available from government data collection programs. a general web search a general web search a general web search a general web search searching within a research data portal searching within a research data portal searching within a research data portal searching within a research data portal searching for data in government data sources searching for data in government data sources searching for data in government data sources searching for data in government data sources you have chosen a research topic about machine learning algorithms for wind power generation. you need to become more familiar with the topic and the types of data that may be available. what would be your choice to begin your search? scenario two searching for data within a peer reviewed article searching for data within a peer reviewed article searching for data within a peer reviewed article searching for data within a peer reviewed article

correct! for an in-depth analysis on the effects of this education program, you would need research data. there is likely to be existing data from prior researchers available for your analysis. this can be the place to start looking, but this kind of data is usually more specific. your general web searches may help lead you to the proper repository. you may find overviews or trends (e.g. crime statistics over the last five years), but the summary data alone can not be used for a cause and effect analysis. itâ€™s not a bad place to start, but news articles are unlikely to directly contain the detail of data you will need for your analysis. a general web search a general web search a general web search a general web search secondary data portal secondary data portal secondary data portal secondary data portal data in the news data in the news data in the news data in the news for your senior project, you are looking for data to analyze the effect of prison education programs on the rate of recidivism (crime relapse). where are you likely to find a dataset that meets your needs? scenario three research data portal research data portal research data portal research data portal

while itâ€™s not always the case, peer reviewed publications often have rather technical visualizations, and may not be the best suited for presentation to a general audience. incorrect that is incorrect. please try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect almost there! the key characteristic of peer-reviewed information is that it has been reviewed by experts in the field, and published through a reputable publisher. peer reviewed information can be found in library or academic databases, and may include summary data, images, or visualizations. while itâ€™s not always the case, peer reviewed publications often have rather technical visualizations, and may not be the best suited for presentation to a general audience. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! the key characteristic of peer-reviewed information is that it has been reviewed by experts in the field, and published through a reputable publisher. peer reviewed information can be found in library or academic databases, and may include summary data, images, or visualizations. while itâ€™s not always the case, peer reviewed publications often have rather technical visualizations, and may not be the best suited for presentation to a general audience. continue continue continue continue continue continue peer reviewed information which of the following statements apply to peer reviewed information? it is reviewed by experts in the authorâ€™s field before publication. it is reviewed by experts in the authorâ€™s field before publication. it is reviewed by experts in the authorâ€™s field before publication. it is reviewed by experts in the authorâ€™s field before publication. it is reviewed by experts in the authorâ€™s field before publication. it is reviewed by experts in the authorâ€™s field before publication. it is reviewed by your peers. it is reviewed by your peers. it is reviewed by your peers. it is reviewed by your peers. it is reviewed by your peers. it is reviewed by your peers. it can be found in library or academic databases. it can be found in library or academic databases. it can be found in library or academic databases. it can be found in library or academic databases. it can be found in library or academic databases. it can be found in library or academic databases. it may include summary data, images, or visualizations. it may include summary data, images, or visualizations. it may include summary data, images, or visualizations. it may include summary data, images, or visualizations. it may include summary data, images, or visualizations. it may include summary data, images, or visualizations. it is the best source of well designed visuals and graphics. it is the best source of well designed visuals and graphics. it is the best source of well designed visuals and graphics. it is the best source of well designed visuals and graphics. it is the best source of well designed visuals and graphics. it is the best source of well designed visuals and graphics. 4 select all that apply

when looking for data sources, infographics may not be the best place to look. certainly, infographics can be useful for viewing example visualizations. incorrect something is wrong in your response. try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect something is wrong in your response. if you selected the keywords datasets, research data, and statistics, youâ€™re on the right track! continue continue continue continue continue continue correct thatâ€™s right! you selected the best keywords for searching for data on the web. these terms could help you find quick facts and statistics, summary datasets, and source datasets. continue continue continue continue continue continue web search tips when searching for data on the web, which of the following keywords are the best to use in addition to your topic? select all that apply. research data research data research data research data research data research data infographic infographic infographic infographic infographic infographic datasets datasets datasets datasets datasets datasets statistics statistics statistics statistics statistics statistics 5 select all that apply

when searching data in the news, you might be able to track down source data by looking at captions for attributions. when searching secondary data portals, you can get access to data from a variety of original sources. when research data portals, you can find discipline-specific data collected in new and original research. incorrect something is wrong in your response. try again. try again try again try again try again try again try again incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue where do you search? drag and drop the search strategy to its correct description. 6 secondary data portals data in the news research data portals when searching here, you can get access to data from a variety of original sources. when searching here, you can find discipline-specific data collected in new and original research. when searching here, you might be able to track down source data by looking at captions for attributions.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Storytelling with Data by Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Incorporating data and visualizations in your work can be an effective way to communicate findings, support your argument, and present information that will stick with your audience. However, finding the right data, and finding that data in a form that you can utilize, is a challenge. 
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="The purpose of this tutorial is to illustrate effective strategies for finding data that you can utilize with your existing research skills
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Since there are hundreds of of potential sites and sources where data can be found, this is less about knowing where to search- but rather, developing a thought process that can reliably lead you to the data you need.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Datasets are made available through a data production process. That is, data must be first be collected and organized; by researchers, by businesses, government organizations and others. Of course, not all of the data that are collected at this stage are made available. The collected data are often reviewed and cleaned, and then made available as a Published Dataset. Finally, this data may go through further analysis or summary, to be presented as key findings.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="As you begin searching for data, it can be helpful to identify what types of data products you encounter, and to consider how they were produced through this process.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="Here are a few guiding questions that can help direct your data search. Each provides a pathway for learning more about the topic, learning what data exists, and learning where that data can be found. Take a few moments to consider these questions in relation to your topic.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Who collects and publishes data on the topic?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="How has this been reported in the news?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="How has this topic been researched by others?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Do other sites aggregate data on this topic?
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="Depending on your topic, not all questions may be applicable, but these usually provide some good ideas on where to look next.
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>

<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Span Text="The rest of the tutorial is organized in two categories. First, what kind of data do you need, and thatâ€™s in terms of how the data is presented. For example, sometimes you need quick summary data, while other times you need a full published dataset to conduct your own analysis. Often this distinction can direct where to search. So the question of what do you need and where to search go hand-in-hand. Second, there are many places where data can be found. This outlines a few different approaches you can take to look for data.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Span Text="In the following slides you can explore each of these options further and form connections between what do you need and where to search. 
" /> </Block> <Block /> </Content> </Document>
